div.p: All measures were the same as those reported in the full study, with the addition of attitudes included in the model. Attitudes. Attitudes were assessed in two primary ways.

Attitude stance. First, students were asked to take a stance with regard to trophy hunting. Specifically, students were asked to respond to the multiple-choice question: do you support trophy hunting? In the sample, 5.98% (n=21) selected yes, I support trophy hunting; 60.40% (n=212) selected no, I don't support trophy hunting; while 6.84% (n=24) of participants reported that they could not decide, and an addition 26.78% (n=94) of participants selected I don't know enough to decide.

Attitude certainty. In addition to reporting their attitude stance, participants were further asked to rate three items corresponding to attitude certainty (i.e., how sure are you, how confident are you, how strongly do you feel). Students rated attitude certainty items on a fivepoint scale, ranging from not at all to very, with attitude certainty able to be rated by students endorsing a variety of attitude stances. That is, students who were both strongly in support of and strongly in opposition to trophy hunting were expected to strongly endorse these items and to be comparably reactive to the texts provided, as these included information both in support of and in opposition to trophy hunting. As a contrast, students without a predefined attitude stance (i.e., selecting the I cannot decide or I don't know enough to decide options) were expected to be more moderate in their ratings of attitude certainty.

These expected associations between attitude stance and attitude certainty was born out in an analysis of variance that found average attitude certainty to significantly differ in association with stance, F(3, 348)=80.28, p<0.001, 洧랙 2 = 0.41. As expected, post-hoc analyses using Tukey's HSD found students supporting (M=3.54, SD=0.89) and opposing (M=3.96, SD=0.96) trophy hunting to have significantly higher degrees of attitude certainty than students selecting the I cannot decide (M=2.42, SD=0.84) or the I don't know enough to decide (M=2.17, SD=1.09) options, ps<0.001. Because attitude certainty functioned separately from students' chosen attitude stance (i.e., students both supporting and opposing trophy hunting had similarly high ratings of attitude certainty) this was the measure used in analyses. Reliability for the three-item attitude certainty scale was 0.94.

div.head: Results for the Model Including Attitude Certainty
div.p: The model including attitudes and other individual difference factors and processing variables to predict multiple text task performance was found to have good data fit, X 2 (103)=174.06, p<0.001. Model fit indices were: CFI = 0.97, RMSEA = 0.05 (90%CI: 0.03 -0.06), SRMR = 0.04. Significant paths and standardized loadings are presented in Figure 9.

Measurement model. All indicators were found to load significantly onto latent factors corresponding to interest (0.61-0.88, p-values<0.001), engagement in information evaluation (0.66-0.79, p-values<0.001), and attitude certainty (0.88-0.97, p-values<0.001).

Mediators. Time on texts was significantly predicted by both students' interest (洧띻 =0.20, p<0.01) and by their habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.13, p<0.05). Students' engagement of strategies reflecting cross-textual elaboration was predicted by their attitudes (洧띻 =0.16, p<0.05) and habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.29, p<0.001).
Integrated mental model development.

Direct paths. Integrated mental model development was only significantly predicted by the amount of time that students devoted to text access, (洧띻 =0.44, p<0.001). None of the other factors had a significant, direct effect on integrated mental model development, p values >12.

Indirect paths. There were additionally two significant mediating paths in the model. In particular, the effects of interest (洧띻 =0.09, p<0.01) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.06, p<0.05) on integrated mental model development was significantly mediated by time devoted to text access.
In total, 24.6% of integrated mental model developed was explained by the model.

div.head: Intertext model development.
div.p: Direct paths. Intertextual model development was also only predicted by the amount of time that students devoted to text access, (洧띻 =0.38, p<0.001). No other direct paths were significant, p values >0.08.

Indirect paths. Again, the effects of interest (洧띻 =0.08, p<0.01) and habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.05, p<0.05) on intertext model development were mediated by the amount of time that students developed to text access.
In total, 19.3% of variance in intertext model development was explained by the model.

div.head: Covariances.
div.p: Interest was significantly associated with students' attitudes (0.41, p<0.001) and habits with regard to information evaluation (0.23, p=0.001). Attitudes were also significantly associated with students' habits with regard to information evaluation (0.14, p<0.05). Integrated mental model construction and inter-text model development were associated with one another (0.37, p<0.001).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Although demonstrating good model fit, students' attitude certainty was not directly associated with any of the outcomes of interest, although it was significantly associated with students' engagement in cross-textual elaboration. As suggested by the CAEM, it may be that holding stronger attitudes on a particular topic is associated with greater strategy use (i.e., engagement in cross-textual elaboration) when students are presented with conflicting texts on a controversial topic. For instance, stronger attitudes may lead students to scrutinize and critically evaluate texts conflicting with their own points of view (McCrudden & Barnes, 2016).

div.head: Group 2: Predicting CTI and SSM Performance
div.p: As in the full model, all indicators loaded significantly onto factors corresponding to interest (0.52-0.94, p-values<0.001) and habits with regard to information evaluation (0.66-0.79, p-values<0.001). Time on texts was significantly predicted by both interest (洧띻 =0.17, p=0.05) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.18, p<0.05), with R 2 =0.08. Students' engagement in cross-textual elaboration was predicted by interest (洧띻 =0.20, p<0.05) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.40, p<0.001), with R 2 =0.23.

Cross-textual integration task performance. Direct effects. CTI task performance was directly predicted only by the time that students devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.37, p<0.001). None of the other direct paths examined in the model were significant, p-values > 0.11.

Indirect effects. Four possible indirect paths were also examined, with only one of these found to be significant. In particular, the effect on students' engagement in information evaluation on CTI performance was found to be significantly mediated by the time that students devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.07, p<0.05).

In total, 19.3% of variance in CTI performance was explained by the model. Statement source match task performance. Direct effects. SSM task performance was only directly predicted by the amount of time that students devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.45, p<0.001), with none of the other direct effects significant in the model.

Indirect effects. There were two significant mediating paths in the model. That is the effects of both interest (洧띻 =0.08, p=0.05) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.08, p<0.05) on SSM performance was significantly mediated by the time that students devoted to text access.
In total, 25.9% of the R 2 variance in SSM performance was explained by the model.

div.head: Covariances.
div.p: Interest was significantly associated with students' habits with regard to information evaluation (0.26, p<0.01). Integrated mental model development was significantly associated with inter-text model development (0.44, p<0.001).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Results from these analyses partially mirrored those found in the full study. First, while interest directly predicted integrated mental model development for Group 1, this path did not rise to significance for Group 2. Second, as in the full model, time was found to have an important direct and indirect effect both on students' integrated mental model and on students' inter-text model development. Third, in analyses for Group 1, students' engagement in crosstextual elaboration significantly predicted inter-text model development; although this path was not found to be significant for Group 2. On a more general level, the analyses conducted across groups, supported the general conclusions suggested by the CAEM. Individual difference factors were associated with a variety of processing variables; processing variables were generally found to predict integration performance. Variables were considered to be approximately normal using +/-1 as a cut-off for skewness and +/-2 as a cut-off for kurtosis. a Because the time variable deviated significantly from normality, eight outliers were removed from the data and the time on texts variable was logarithmically transformed.

figure.figDesc: examined the direct and indirect effects of individual difference factors on students' processing of multiple texts and, ultimately, on multiple text comprehension. Four individual difference factors were examined. These were (a) prior knowledge, (b) need for cognition, (c) epistemic beliefs about the need for knowledge to be justified by multiple sources, and (d) individual interest. Processing variables examined included situational interest, deeplevel strategy use, and effort, as assessed via the time that students devoted to multiple text access. Multiple text comprehension, asking students to consider or integrate disparate perspectives when responding to a series of open-ended questions, was examined as the outcome variable of interest and directly predicted only by prior knowledge. Students' deep-level strategy use was found to mediate the association between prior knowledge, epistemic beliefs, and need for cognition and multiple text comprehension performance. Effort devoted to multiple text use mediated the relation between individual interest and epistemic beliefs and multiple text comprehension. In sum, findings from Br친ten et al. (2014) point to the mediating role of processing variables on students' comprehension of multiple texts. Moreover, their work suggests that a variety of individual difference factors, both cognitive and affective, have an effect on students' multiple text task performance. Present Study in Relation to Prior Work Modeling Learning from Multiple Texts This paper complements and expands work by Lund et al. (2019), Kobayashi (2009), and Br친ten et al. (2014) in at least three ways. First, like Lund et al. (2019) and Kobayashi (2009), I examine the associations among a variety of multiple text-related outcomes, including measures of inter-text and integrated mental model construction, as facets of integration. Moreover, like Br친ten et al. (2014), I include processing variables as mediating the relationship between individual difference factors and students' multiple text task performance. Finally, like both Lund et al. (2019) and Br친ten et al. (2014), I include both cognitive and affective individual difference factors in predicting multiple text processing and performance. As such, this study models the associations among cognitive and affective individual difference factors and multiple text task performance, assessed via measures of integration, and mediated by multiple text

Consistent with Figure 1, three types of measures, reflecting individual difference factors, process variables, and performance outcomes were examined. While individual difference factors were assessed prior to task completion, process variables and performance outcomes were assessed within the context of a multiple text task. Individual difference factors. Six individual differences were assessed in this study (i.e., prior knowledge, interest, habits with regard to information evaluation, attitudes, need for cognition, and justification by multiple texts). The individual difference factors correspondent to the CAEM are introduced in the methods, while attitudes (Appendix B), need for cognition (Appendix A), and justification by multiple texts (Appendix A) are discussed in the appendices wherein these factors are analyzed.

. In reporting results, I first describe loadings onto each latent construct in the measurement model, then results are introduced in terms of the direct and indirect paths predicting each outcome measure of interest (i.e., integrate mental model and intertext model development). Finally, additional relations in the model are d. Direct and indirect loadings are summarized in Table8.Factor loadings in the measurement modelInterest. Each of four items loaded significantly onto the interest factor (0.61-0.89), p-values<0.001.Information evaluation. Each of six items loaded significantly onto the information evaluation factor (0.66-0.79), p-values<0.001.Integrated Mental ModelDirect effects. Four direct effects (i.e., interest, students' habits with regard to information evaluation, total time, cross-textual elaboration) on integrated mental model development were examined in the model. However, only interest (洧띻=0.11, p=0.05) and the time that students devoted to text access (洧띻=0.44, p<0.001) had a significant direct effect on integrated mental model development.Indirect effects. Four mediating paths were examined in the model (i.e., interest via time on texts; interest via cross-textual elaboration; information evaluation via time on texts; information evaluation via cross-textual elaboration) as predicting students' integrated mental model development. Two of these indirect paths were significant. First, interest predicted integrated mental model development, as mediated by time (洧띻=0.09, p<0.01). Second, the relation between students' habits with regard to information evaluation and integrated mental model development were also significantly mediated by time (洧띻=0.06, p<0.05).In total, 24.3% of the variance in integrated mental model development was explained by the direct and indirect effects in the model, suggesting a large effect.Intertext ModelDirect effects. Four direct effects were further examined as predicting intertext model development. The time that students devoted to text access (洧띻=0.37, p<0.001) and students' engagement in cross-textual elaboration (洧띻=0.10, p=0.05) were found to have a direct effect on inter-text model formation.Indirect effects. Additionally, two of the four possible mediating effects in the model were found to be significant. That is the effect of both interest (洧띻=0.08, p<0.01) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻=0.05, p<0.05) on inter-text model development were both found to be significantly mediated by the time that students devoted to text access.In total, 19.0% of variance in inter-text model development was explained by the direct and indirect effects in the model, indicating a medium effect.

, which suggest that students' degree of topic interest, as well as other motivational factors, matter a great deal for multiple text task completion. Second, this study separately modeled two outcomes associated with multiple text integration -integrated mental model and inter-text model development. While integrated mental model development corresponded to students forming a unified and coherent understanding of a particular topic, inter-text model development reflected students' structural understanding of information as coming from specific sources of origin and cross-source connection formation. While integrated mental model construction seems integral to learning from multiple texts, the purpose of inter-text model construction may be less clear.

div.head: Appendix A
div.p: Replicating analyses by Br친ten et al. (2014), I ran a latent path model to examine the associations among individual difference factors, processing variables, and multiple text task performance. Individual difference factors included were: topic interest, need for cognition, and students' endorsements of epistemic beliefs associated with the need to justify knowledge based on multiple texts. Processing factors included were: time devoted to text access, referred to by Br친ten et al. (2014) as an indicator of effort, and students' reports of engagement in cross-textual elaboration. Outcome measures examined included measures of integrated mental model and inter-text model development.

These analyses differed from Br친ten et al.'s (2014) model in four ways. First, this study modeled individual difference factors as latent, rather than observed, variables. Second, this study did not include prior knowledge due to limitations in the reliability of this measure. Third, this study did not have a measure of situational interest as a processing factor. Four, this study examined an integration-focused set of multiple text learning outcomes including measures of integrated mental model and inter-text model development. The theorized model evaluated is presented in Figure 3.

div.head: Methods
div.p: All measures used were the same as those reported in the full study, with two additional individual difference factors examined.

Need for cognition. Need for cognition was a six-item measure based on Cacioppo, Petty, and Kao (1984). Only six items (e.g., I prefer complex to simple problems; I like situations that require a lot of thinking) were taken from the 18-item measure (i.e., those with the highest loadings), due to concerns over study length. Students rated each item on a five-point scale from strongly disagree to strongly agree. The six-item scale had a Cronbach's alpha reliability of 0.88.

Justifications for knowing by multiple texts. Students' endorsement of epistemic beliefs that knowledge ought be justified via multiple texts was assessed using four items from Ferguson and Br친ten's (2013) Justification by Multiple Sources beliefs sub-scale. Items included: Just one source is never enough to decide what is right and To be able to trust information in texts, I have to check various sources. Each item was scored on a five-point Likert scale from strongly disagree to strongly agree. Cronbach's alpha reliability for the four-item scale was 0.74.

div.head: Model Replicating Br친ten et al. (2014)
div.p: The model using individual difference factors and processing variables to predict multiple text task performance was found to have less than desired data fit, X 2 (119)=249.30, p<0.001. Model fit indices were: CFI = 0.94, RMSEA = 0.06 (90%CI: 0.05 -0.07), SRMR = 0.05. In particular, the CFI index fell below the desired value of greater than 0.95 (Hooper et al., 2008). Significant direct paths and standardized loadings are presented in Figure 4. Direct and indirect paths are summarized in Table 9.

Measurement model. All indicators were found to load significantly onto latent factors corresponding to interest (0.61-0.89, p-values<0.001), need for cognition (0.68-0.85, p-values<0.001), and beliefs about justification by multiple texts (0.52-0.73, p-values<0.001).

div.head: Appendix C Representation of Arguments in Study Texts
div.p: The Economic Benefits of Trophy Hunting A. Trophy hunting raises substantial money for animal conservation. . . In total, trophy hunting generates $200 million annually for wildlife conservation in sub-Saharan Africa. Such a substantial sum of money for wildlife conservation could not otherwise be raised without the exorbitant fees that Westerners pay for trophy hunting licenses.

div.head: B. Trophy hunting also benefits local communities in Africa, contributing to rural development.
div.p: Wildlife is the property of rural villages in the surrounding areas. In Zimbabwe, rural district councils allow villages to sell hunting licenses to safari operators, granting them access to their wildlife. Safari operators, in turn, sell opportunities for trophy hunting to wealthy foreigners, primarily from the United States... Selling access to their wildlife, via trophy hunting licenses is often one of the few ways that rural villages are able to make money.

div.head: The Economic Harms of Trophy Hunting
div.p: A. While a common claim is that trophy hunting raises substantial funds for impoverished African nations, in fact, the trophy hunting industry is quite small, relative to the broader African tourism industry. For instance, in 2014 researchers from Princeton University found that while 8,500 trophy hunters visited South Africa each year, a staggering 9.5 million tourists did so. The tourism industry provides many more local jobs at hotels, restaurants, and wildlife parks, than does trophy hunting.

To the extent that the tourism industry rests on wildlife conservation, it can raise substantially more funds that trophy hunting, while those working in the tourism industry become personally and financially invested in wildlife conservation.

div.head: Appendix D
div.p: In addition to evaluating a model where measures of inter-text and integrated mental model development are collapsed, I also evaluated a multigroup effects model, where students' performance on the SVT, as a measure of integrated mental model development, and the SDT, as an indicator of inter-text model formation was evaluated separately from a second group of students, completing the CTI, as a measure of integrated mental model development, and the SSM, as a measure of inter-text model formation. All other measures and paths were identical to those examined in the collapsed model (See Figure 7 for the theoretical model evaluated). Models for each group, with significant direct paths represented, are presented separately in Figures 8 and9. Direct and indirect paths across groups are summarized in Table 11.

div.head: Overall Model Fit:
div.p: The overall model had good data fit, X 2 (134)=217.76, p<0.001; Group 1 X 2 =89.68; Group 2, X 2 =128.08. Model fit indices included CFI = 0.95, RMSEA = 0.06 (90%CI: 0.05 -0.08), and SRMR=0.05.

div.head: Group 1: Predicting SVT and SDT Performance
div.p: As in the full model, all indicators were found to load significantly onto interest (0.68-0.84, p-values<0.001) and students' habits with regard to information evaluation (0.68-0.78, p-values<0.001).

Mediators. Total time was only predicted by students' interest (洧띻 =0.24, p<0.01), while cross-textual elaboration was predicted by students' habits with regard to information evaluation (洧띻 =0.22, p<0.05), but not by interest (p >0.13). In total, R 2 was 0.07 for the time devoted to text access and 0.08 for students' engagement in cross-textual elaboration.

Statement verification task performance. Direct effects. Performance on the statement verification task was significantly predicted by interest (洧띻 =0.14, p<0.05) and by the amount of time that students devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.53, p<0.001).

Indirect effects. Four mediating paths were examined, however, only one of these was significant. In particular, the effect on interest on integrated mental model development was significantly mediated by the time that students devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.13, p<0.01).
In total 33.5% of variance in SVT performance was explained by the model.

div.head: Source differentiation performance.
div.p: Direct effects. The time that students devoted to multiple text access (洧띻 =0.29, p<0.001) and students' engagement of strategies reflecting cross-textual elaboration (洧띻 =0.15, p<0.05) were significant direct predictors of source differentiation performance.

Indirect effects. Four mediating paths were examined, in association with source differentiation performance, however only one of these was found to be significant. That is, interest was significantly associated with SDT performance, as mediated via time devoted to text access (洧띻 =0.07, p<0.05).
In total 13.0% of variance in SDT performance was explained by the model.

div.head: Covariances.
div.p: Interest was not significantly associated with students' habits with regard to information evaluation (0.21, p=0.06). Integrated mental model development was significantly associated with inter-text model development (0.31, p<0.001).
